title: Champion Complexity is Too Damn High!
body:
Hi boards,

I have noticed quite a number of players, on the boards and otherwise, discussing certain "Outdated" champions. Ones which supposedly _**need**_ to be updated to suit "modern" league. I feel this is the wrong direction to go. If you would like to hear why I believe this, strap in and keep reading!

{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-popcorn}} 

Champs like {{champion:9}} or {{champion:1}}, who have shortish range, simple kits, point and click spells and CC have seen some attention recently on these boards suggesting updates to help them keep up. And aye, they might benefit from them. But I have one plea for riot should these changes occur: Keep them simple.

Point and click champions need to exist. Stat check champions are necessary, or there is nothing meaningful to outplay. League is not a fighting game, it is a MOBA, a strategic team game that at its best is capable of supporting an incredible chess-like ecosystem of champion archetypes that are far more than the simple "lul 420 outplayed me edgy" champions.

Imagine, if you will, a world where every spell was a skillshot,  such as with {{champion:101}}. 
As exceedingly mobile champions sail across the rift, a beleaguered legion of reluctant sharpshooters struggle in vain to hit the {{champion:84}}{{champion:157}}{{champion:497}}{{champion:555}}{{champion:81}} as they sail freely through the air. Feebly sipping their coffee as carpal tunnel sets in and frustration mounts, the screen goes gray.

Numbers definitely need to be kept tuned low on simple, point and click, champions, but they NEED to exist. With each older, simpler, legacy champion to be reworked and removed, a little bit of league history dies, and league becomes ever more frustrating to play as high-skill difficult champions predominate. Part of why league feels so volatile at the moment is simply the fact that playing sub-optimally on these champions causes such awful, unavoidable feeding.

Although I understand the frustration of seeing those older champions unable to compete with the new generation of extremely overloaded, book long kits, I want to pause to briefly argue for the beauty of these older, simpler kits...

Older champion designs, with simplistic, limited kits, and defined strengths and weaknesses, are being phased out. E.g Old {{champion:10}} ,{{champion:39}} ,{{champion:84}},{{champion:104}}, {{champion:266}}  

One thing all of these reworks have in common? All of them (Save Kayle possibly, but I have specific issues with her I will write about later) have been much, much harder to keep properly balanced, and are significantly more frustrating both to learn and to fight against than their prior iterations. The difference between their ability in execution between divisions makes them an incredible nuisance in higher elo (Tired of seeing them in streams), and a much greater liability for the 95% of the player-base that simply isn't that good at the game. If this pattern continues, I will soon have nothing to play as all of my beloved old clunkers will have been replaced with hyper-mobile complicated messes.

Many of these reworks have exceedingly long, complicated, multi-passived and multi-parted kits that have so many moving parts it is little wonder that the balance team often takes several patches to tune these champions. 

In the interest of maintaining player interest in new releases, and to pursue an ever shrinking design space for new champions and rework ideas, Riot has made increasingly complex, difficult to balance, and gimmicky champions and reworks. Although this is understandable, steps need to be taken, and soon, to reduce complexity creep to a bearable level.

replies.body:
I can see some of your point (and have upvoted it for visibility), but I have only partial agreement. I almost never see many of those champions, and many of them ARE fairly simple in concept/description. They are crowded out a bit at the moment, though.

{{champion:45}} IS a point and click champion. Satisfying to use as well.

Champions like {{champion:84}} {{champion:39}} {{champion:157}}{{champion:555}}  are in every single game, and are silly complex. And they are mostly quite recent. 

I'd adore seeing more Cass, Rumble, Asol, Poppy, Bard, Braum, Tf, and Varus. They are all wonderful, unique champions, and despite the difficulty in playing some of them, they are examples of good, non-frustrating champion design(and simple in theory). They are also much rarer to see, particularly on high elo streams.

Fiddle is irritating, but at least he can answer the hypermobility goon squad meaningfully.

Agreed on jax and doge. They are too strong early/mid for how unbelievable they are late. Arguably a numbers problem and a game pacing issue, though.

It very much is for those two, and a item issue (Nasus' issue is how the stacking is 1 to 1 for his Q, feel like they could rework the stacking into something else, maybe like a reward system of sorts, like getting 100 stacks gives you bonus lifesteal (change the passive to 10% lifesteal and stack system), 300 gives you exta damage on Q based on a ratio per stack, etc. Something interactive of sorts. And it caps at, 2000 or something?

Jax on the other hand is reaping the rewards of a hybrid kit with burst damage (irelia's hybrid is actually more in dueling than burst compared to Jax, jax does it harder), and cdr being hella abundant.

Meaningful skill expression? 

{{champion:22}} ?

A while back when i checked the difference between a beginner Ashe and a main was like 5% winrate....from 48% to 52%.


Looking at Aurelion the difference between a newbie and a main is like 10 to 20% winrate instead. 


You can make those older champs work, but its far more rewarding to just master the more complicated ones as they tend to have more tools and more versatile ones at that, even if conditional, at their disposal.

{{champion:145}} for contrast to Ashe.


No if we are talking simple but modern then {{champion:498}}  is probably the best example........she has a significant difference in winrate between newbies and mains, she works in any elo and can deal with almost anything.

Ashe meanwhile sucks horribly against mobility, she is terrible against strong divers or assassins or poke and she is generally terrible above low elo until proplay where she isnt even played much as a marksmen, more like a ult bot for initiation,.....'


Oh actually {{champion:110}}  is probably the superior version of Ashe now that i think about it.......similar ranges, same mobility but he also works in every elo and is more rewarding to master.



I seriously disagree with multiple of your choices of who goes into which category, you really dont seem to know what you are on about from my perspective {{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}}
The matchup knowledge burden too play league has become huge, without playing a load of games on Akali how are you supposed too be able too tell when she is out of dashes?
And know her cooldowns? Energy costs? The delay between R and second R?

> Stat check champions are necessary

Much love from all Jax and Riven mains

: )

Problem children. I will freely admit that I play neither (Jax is always banned for good reasons and a potato could play riven better than I).

I admit the necessity of your existence, but would you kindly stop being so damn good at EVERY phase of the game? Riven and Jax are actually fairly overloaded champions in and of themselves. 

But it is fine. It is mostly the fault of numbers tuning/itemization issues more than those champions being inherently problematic.

imagine a world where every champion was master yi, so fun, such a fun play style.

shyvana, being an auto attacker, isn't a point and click champion, and feels fair to fight. other champs not so much.

Yi is a problem. It is true. But he is an outlier. And it isnt his relative simplicity that is the problem, it is item interactions that make balancing him a nightmare. Tbh if you let attack speed slows work on him it would help immensely. 

Shyvana feels terrible right now except for the busted AP variant.

There is ample room for simple champs without permitting niche frustration cases.
I disagree. Many feel that complexity is very interesting. In regards to your title of this post, my response is: Good.

You like cake. I like pie. Why can't both exist? It would be one thing if simple champs still occurred every once in a while, but the majority of recent releases are incredibly complex, overloaded messes that have proven incredibly difficult to balance successfully...

Should be noted that I started playing during a much, much, MUCH simpler League of Legends. I am biased and spoiled by the tactical complexity that was possible even without requiring extensive mechanical/kit complexity. High skill champions existed, so did simpler button mashers that provided ample opportunity to play the map instead of sweating that sick insec combo.

Complexity generally means overloaded messes that cover their own weaknesses and are unilaterally frustrating to play against, and more difficult to learn/play for those who, like most of mankind over the age of 18, don't have a ton of time to devote to league.

However, releases such as {{champion:39}} {{champion:84}} {{champion:266}} {{champion:10}} ended up as incredibly overcomplex monstrosities compared to their prior iterations. Since their release they have been the source of ample frustration and salt, and the patches in the interim spent attempting to bring them back into line have been absolutely painful. I'm not resistant to changes and reworks occurring. I just plead that they remain thematically simple.

You mention fiddle being reworked and the biggest reason the devs gave for his rework is because his kit isn't thematic enough. His kit is still viable to an extent but they want to make him more nuanced and rewarding to ppl that actually main him. {{champion:266}} for example

Aatrox is a terrible example. His rework feels absolutely nothing like the original Aatrox. Now hes draintank bruisery Riven. They essentially scrapped his entire kit without exception and replaced it in its entirety. If they do that to Fiddlesticks I will legitimately cry. 

Some change is fine, necessary even, but please keep him feeling like fiddle. Make his fear have a delay, but keep it point and click. Keep his ult a playmaker. Make sure he still feels like the spooky guy we all know him to be. Riot already completely altered my Kayle to an unrecognizable polarized mess, leave stickles alone! And please keep the kit simple enough that I don't need a doctoral thesis to learn the darn thing.

Aatrox is more rewarding to play, but most of the people I know who mained him don't think he's thematically Aatrox now. His mains now are the usually those who have found and adored him strictly since the rework. In which case it begs the question why they bothered to release this as a rework at all, instead of simply releasing a new champion entirely.
I just wish there was a champion like Invoker from dota on league.
